item.title: Ottoman floating point zip bombs on the moon
item.description: Programming Floating point routines for 6502 by Woz (direct link) A better zip bomb ; NON-RECURSIVE zip-bombs that extract from 42 kB to‚Ä¶
item.content:encoded:
Programming

  • Floating point routines for 6502 by Woz

    (direct link)

  • A better zip bomb; NON-RECURSIVE zip-bombs that extract from 42 kB to 5.5 GB, from 10MB to 281TB, or from 46MB to 4.5PB (last one is Zip64 and not as compatible). Non-recursive means you get that amount of date in a single extract operation.

    Not quite useful information, but interesting nonetheless.

Articles

  • Designing the First Full-Time Human Habitat on the Moon, original press-release

    Just a proposal, though.

  • Humans Who Are Not Concentrating Are Not General Intelligences

    TL;DR: As I continue to dig through the swarm of articles that appeared in the wake of OpenAI's GPT-2, here's another fine one. Quite humbling, as it finds that we humans ourselves cannot be considered general intelligences unless we concentrate enough.

  • A philosopher argues that an AI can‚Äôt be an artist

    TL;DR: in other news, water is still wet

    NB: it's behind a paywall, but I didn't read the whole article anyway.

  • The Mystery of Florida's Cannonball-eating Fort

    TL;DR: it was made of coquina; that's a stone that's while visually similar to sandstone has different structure and behaves more like foam under stress.

    "Saved you a click," I'd say, but there are some nice pictures of the cannonball and bullet holes in the coquina walls of the castle.

  • Speaking of Moon, NASA Will Open Pristine, Sealed Samples of Moon Rock

    If I read that right, they'll open one of the six pristine sealed moon rocks that were sealed 50 years ago in hope that future technologies may tell us more about them (and that future happens to be now). We're unlikely to get more pristine untouched moon rock samples until at least 2024, but I sure hope we will.

Games

  • Excalibur / Adventuron

    An online text adventure, in ZX Spectrum visual style, and a tool to create one of your own!

    (Didn't dig into this deep enough, sadly; might write an update later)

  • Grid Cartographer ‚Äî a tool to create maps for your tabletop and computer games

    Steam, Site, Twitter

    (via @ben_304)

Music

  • Felix Marc - Substance

    (bandcamp, also available on Spotify, iTunes, amazon music, YouTube Music, Google play, Deezer, any Russian MP3 pirate server and NSA databases)

    Sad and beautiful dark wave/synth pop album from Germany, that you have to buy digitally and burn on your own CD-r

  • Grindmother - Age of Destruction

    And for something completely different, here's some old-style grindcore, so old-style their vocalist is, like, 70 years old or something.

Art

  • Miniature Russian garbage dump - unfortunately, I couldn't find the source

  • Ottoman Bird Palaces

item.title: Live-coding long-term lewd asshole torture storage
item.description: Programming Live coding a vi for CP/M, from scratch Somewhat related (and ancient), Linux on an 8-bit micro by emulating an ARM processor‚Ä¶
item.content:encoded:
Programming

  • Live coding a vi for CP/M, from scratch

  • Somewhat related (and ancient), Linux on an 8-bit micro by emulating an ARM processor, no less! (slower than molasses, obviously, like, literally, hours to boot)

  • Also related, Why 80s BASIC still matters! - this made me want to buy the book, and I probably will.

Articles

  • Inside the World's First Long-term Storage Facility for Highly Radioactive Nuclear Waste

    Some nice photos there.

  • Why torture doesn't work

    Quite an obvious one, in retrospect; still, horrible how many people get this wrong to this day.

  • Loos, Lewdness, and Literature: Tales from the Boghouse

    TL;DR: a review of an 18th century anthology of toilet poetry. Quite brave for the time!

  • Space station mold can survive a lot of radiation

    Oh well, and there goes Gerard O'Neill's suggestion to sterilize everything that goes to space cylinder colonies to avoid dangerous bacteria and organisms. Life, uh, finds a way, so to say.

  • Don't Hire Assholes

    TL;DR: there's also ways to un-asshole some assholes

Art

  • Pied wagtail (photo)

item.title: Don't take fractal fireball notes written in FORTH
item.description: Programming 1991: A SERVER-SIDE WEB FRAMEWORK WRITTEN IN FORTH , github BECAUSE OF COURSE Articles Don't take notes with a laptop TL;DR‚Ä¶
item.content:encoded:
Programming

  • 1991: A SERVER-SIDE WEB FRAMEWORK WRITTEN IN FORTH, github

    BECAUSE OF COURSE

Articles

  • Don't take notes with a laptop

    TL;DR: This has been told again and again, but hand-writing lecture notes makes you remember them better (and makes your hands hurt a lot)

  • Floppycasts!

    TL;DR: if satisfied with absolutely terrifying quality, you can fit about 22 minutes of MP3 speech on a floppy disk, or about 30 minutes of Opus (approximately as terrifying but in a different way)

    I might've done something like this if I wasn't so ashamed of my own voice.

  • Why grape turns into a fireball in a microwave

  • Oumuamua is not an alien spaceship, but Can we catch the next "Oumuamua"?

  • Life is fractal, but markets are square ‚Äî very insightful

Just useful

  • https://www.privacytools.io/

Music

  • Tapage & Gareth Davis - STATES (bandcamp)

    This is some music produced by an electronic setup that is allowed to self-influence and produce music until it reaches some stable state.

    There's also a sax player providing some atmosphere.

Games

  • The Crimson Diamond

    A text-parser adventure game in a quite fitting EGA graphics style. The free demo can be rough around the edges, but I hope the game will be finished some day.

  • Interview with Philip Oliver of Oliver Twins (youtube)

  • Interview with Andrew Oliver of Oliver Twins (youtube)

Art

  • Wiki Titles Signable to TMNT Theme Song

  • Everyday life of modern Ghibli couples

item.title: Next level mead and honey outcome of amateur opossum romance

Programming

    WARNING: it's a fork bomb, don't paste it anywhere!

Articles

  • FunKey

    TL;DR: TL;DR: A keychain with a bunch of emulators, some buttons and an LCD screen; like a really tiny nintendo ds

  • Stardock and Star Control creators settle lawsuits‚Äîwith mead and honey

    TL;DR: The kind of news headline you read first thing in the morning and do a double take

  • The Yellow Submarine of Coney Island Creek

    TL;DR: A failed art brut submarine made in 1970 to salvage a ship sunk in 1956, still laying there near New York

Music

  • –¢–∞—Ç—É - –ù–∞—Å –Ω–µ –¥–æ–≥–æ–Ω—è—Ç Killed by Lazers remix

    (the song also had an English version called Not Gonna Get Us)

  • 16-Ê≠¶Ë£ÖÁøº„ÅÆÂ•≥Á•û - CATASTROPHIC OUTCOME OF PROGRESS

    They're called "16ArmedWingedGoddess" and they play... cybergrind, I guess. With track titles and band name in Japanese, even though they are, as far as I am aware, American.

Games

    Didn't play it yet, but come on, a shark dating sim?

item.title: Russian independence day special
item.description: Programming On Dat:// TL;DR: Dat is a distributed web network, and this post talks about building a clone of an old (and dead) mixtape‚Ä¶
item.content:encoded:
Programming

  • On Dat://

    TL;DR: Dat is a distributed web network, and this post talks about building a clone of an old (and dead) mixtape-sharing website muxtape with it, called duxtape (github).

    Suffice it to say, I am very interested.

Articles

  • You (probably) don't need ReCAPTCHA

    TL;DR: (probably) yes

    I myself quite liked the proof-of-work captcha concept (i.e. "mine some hashes for me if you want to comment; if you want to spam a lot, it's ok, just mine a lot of hashes")

  • What is ZIL anyway?

    TL;DR: Andrew Plotkin on the Infocom ZIP dump, with an addendum by Tim Anderson

  • Circle Games

    TL;DR: why babies like repetitive games like peek-a-boo, and how repetition be perceived as both boring or rewarding depending on context

Music

  • Jozef Van Wissem & Jim Jarmusch - An Attempt to Draw Aside the Veil

    An album of nice psychedelic drones, sometimes with acoustic guitar, and generally with certain mescalinic deserty feel to them.

Art

  • Hiroyuki Doi‚Äôs Tiny Circles

item.title: Horrifying Satanic Space Colonies: Odyssey
item.description: Programming Horrifying PDF experiments e.g. breakout Articles How to Join a Social Network in 1998 TL;DR you mail them CSV of your friends‚Ä¶
item.content:encoded:
Programming

  • Horrifying PDF experiments

    • e.g. breakout

Articles

  • How to Join a Social Network in 1998

    TL;DR you mail them CSV of your friends in response

  • Ancient Egyptian Bread (unrolled here)

  • Paradigms and priors

    TL;DR how science works

  • I found two identical packs of Skittles among 468 packs

    TL;DR why

  • Can we all please stop using medium?

Music

  • Gorelord - Force Fed On Human Flesh

    This death metal album by Necrophagia's once-guitarist Frediablo (featuring guest vocals by Necrophagia's late front-man Killjoy) was an album that I have somehow missed previously.

    Although it was released couple of years before The Divine Art of Torture, so it's more of a predecessor, I guess?

    Missing are Mirai Kawashima's chilling synth works. Or, really, any synths. If that's your thing. Still, it's quite nice.

  • desert drone cycle by cristopher cichocki

    Some nice and chilled drones, available on tape and digitally

Images

  • Face of an ancient dog

  • Satanic^W Panamic Cushion Starfish

Games

  • Borrowed Super Mario Odyssey from a friend at work, started playing it. Looks and plays nice, not very hard.

    One may call it a bab game, not a schut one.

Books

  • Reading The High Frontier: Human Colonies in Space by Gerard K. O'Neill, since it acquired some new interest lately (e.g. Jeff Bezos's talk on the subject), and it reads like half science fiction and half talk in front of the Congress or something (and, in fact, was both of these). Very romantic, and I do hope we'll colonize the space some day. As opposed to perishing somewhere in 2050s, at least.

item.title: Bizzarre Japanese sorting and exploding things
item.description: Programming Sorting in Japanese is hard There are four Japanese women whose names you have to sort: Junko, Atsuko, Kiyoko, and Akiko. This‚Ä¶
item.content:encoded:
Programming

  • Sorting in Japanese is hard

    There are four Japanese women whose names you have to sort: Junko, Atsuko, Kiyoko, and Akiko. This does not seem difficult, until they each show you how they write their names in kanji:

    • Ê∑≥Â≠ê (Junko)
    • Ê∑≥Â≠ê (Atsuko)
    • Ê∑≥Â≠ê (Kiyoko)
    • Ê∑≥Â≠ê (Akiko)

  • AMP for email is a terrible idea

    TL;DR: yes.

Articles

  • Israel's Moon lander crashed, and that's OK

    TL;DR: Still, it was quite a feat, and they'll likely continue trying.

    (Although I thought the correct term for it was "lithobraking", not "crashing" xD)

  • How to quit caffeine in one week

    (NB: premium article)

    TL;DR: It's apparently not that hard and can be done in the course of a couple of weeks. Tyrosine and/or phenylalanine supplements are recommended.

  • Four new DNA letters double life‚Äôs alphabet

    TL;DR: scientists created four more artificial bases that can be used in place of (or together with) the usual ATGC in the DNA. This artificial DNA can even be transcribed onto RNA, but more tests are necessary.

  • Normalization of Deviance

    TL;DR: Just a good engineering rant by @Foone on why things fail

  • Is the Hard Problem of Consciousness Connected to the Hard Problem in Physics?

    TL;DR: everything is, like, conscious because physics is, like, not absolute truth and just, like, theories, and, like, electrons must have expierences like ours because how else would we get consciense, like, dude, now pass me some more of that lsd

Music

  • Neural network generating technical death metal, via livestream 24/7 to infinity.

Art

  • Bracelli‚Äôs Bizzarie di Varie Figure

    Very trippy and abstract for 1624, I like

Games

  • Switch'N'Shoot is surprisingly good

Books

  • Still reading The Book Thief by Markus Zusak. It's cute and sad. I've seen the movie when it came out, but don't remember much of it.

item.title: Can't unsee these insecure Wordpress plugins
item.description: Programming Water is still wet. In other news, wordpress plugin ecosystem is still trash a ball of slimy writhing unspeakable horrors. one‚Ä¶
item.content:encoded:
Programming

  • Water is still wet. In other news, wordpress plugin ecosystem is still trash a ball of slimy writhing unspeakable horrors.

    • one
    • two
    • hackernews discussion

    TL;DR: If you ever used anything from these "pipdig" guys on your wordpress or blogger site, please stop asap.

    I personally recommend switching to Hugo instead (do as I say, not as I do; you generally don't need the complexity of Gatsby).

  • Just throwing it out there: Disk encryption for low-end hardware, Linux Journal

Articles

  • Feynman on Fermat's Last Theorem

    TL;DR: Richard Feynman once proved that the probability of Fermat's Last Theorem to be true is less than 10‚Äì31% and concluded: "for my money Fermat‚Äôs theorem is true".

  • They Really Don‚Äôt Make Music Like They Used To

    TL;DR: "Loudness wars" history and analysis; and also why a release sometimes sounds way better on a vinyl record even though technically a CD has much wider dynamic range. (spoiler: it's usually sacrificed to make the album sound louder)

  • Astronomers hunting for the spy satellites

Music

  • Skyminds by Skyminds (available digitally and on cassette from auasca)

    Quite pleasant drone/ambient with some bluesy/desert rock kind of tunes.

    "Desert Winds" track reminds me of Fallout 2 a bit, so there's that.

Art, also music

  • This is what it sounds like when you play all 265 Motorhead songs at the same time

    TL;DL: Just as you imagine

Games

  • TES Arena Remapped

    This may sound like a custom maps set for TES: Arena, but it is not.

    In fact it's just a custom keyboard map for DosBOX to get modern WASD-style controls etc.

  • Can't Unsee

Books

  • Martian Time-Slip by Philip K. Dick

    Starts as silly Mars colonization sci-fi, ends up deep in scizophrenia and mindfuckery. Exactly what I like to read.

  • How We'll Live on Mars by Stephen L. Petranek

    And for something (a bit) more realistic, here's this TED Book about future Mars colonisation (already dated, even though it was published in 2014 iirc).

item.title: Garfield phones, x-ray records and phone tombs
item.description: Programming Exercises in Emulation: Xbox 360‚Äôs FMA Instruction Articles (quote) Algorithmic recommendations ... are failing users by‚Ä¶
item.content:encoded:
Programming

  • Exercises in Emulation: Xbox 360‚Äôs FMA Instruction

Articles

  • (quote) Algorithmic recommendations [...] are failing users by encouraging them to take their interests to the farthest maximum: a you like coffee; have you tried cocaine? kind of effect. Are these features necessary?

  • What Achilles should have said to the Tortoise

  • Garfield phones beach mystery finally solved after 35 years

  • Procrastination Sucks ‚Äî So Here‚Äôs The ‚ÄúEat That Frog‚Äù Way to Powerful Productivity

    TL;DR start with the things that intimidate you the most because they are likely the most important ones anyway.

Art

  • X-Ray Audio is an archive of old Soviet illicit records scratched onto discarded x-ray films.

  • As an addendum, here's an auction for some newly-produced ones.

  • The Tomb and the Telephone Box: Soane‚Äôs Mausoleum (1816)

    And here's how the classic british phone booth shape is inspired by some tomb.

Games

  • Still playing Trials Rising on Switch, it's a nice game (and if you buy it on cartridge, you get a set of stickers, which is nice).

    Sadly, it drops frames at times (mostly on fade-in/out between screens, so it's not like it affects gameplay a lot, but still).

    More sadly, there's a lot of resource popping, e.g. when you die and restart the track, you clearly see that the textures for the beginning of the track has been unloaded already and can take some time to load.

    EVEN MORE SAD ARE MICROTRANSACTIONS AND LOOTBOXES

Books

  • Wampeters, Foma & Granfalloons by Kurt Vonnegut

    A collection of interviews, essays and lectures (and one short dramatic piece).

    His review of Hesse's Steppenwolf made me read that as well.

Music

No albums from the last couple of weeks really retained in my memory.

However, I've seen Prurient perform live, and it was way too awesome!

item.title: Doom, Fire and Wombats
item.description: Programming How Doom fire was done A short and to the point tutorial. ("Doom" here refers to PSX and N64 Doom ports) Articles Going old‚Ä¶
item.content:encoded:
Programming

  • How Doom fire was done

    A short and to the point tutorial. ("Doom" here refers to PSX and N64 Doom ports)

Articles

  • Going old school: how I replaced Facebook with email

    In fact, this is what finally inspired me to do this blog

  • How to balance full-time work with creative projects

    TL;DR: Find a better job, don't think you'll be able to do a lot anyway

Art

  • ‚ÄúO Uommibatto‚Äù: How the Pre-Raphaelites Became Obsessed with the Wombat

    Wombats are great, I totally understand them :D

Games

  • The Ultimate Tape Archive (C64)

    A collection of C64/C128 tapes digitized and with scans. Playable in browser!

    (via https://twitter.com/textfiles/status/1107107236248195073)

  • Mortal Kombat X, or XL, or whatever.

    It was cheap on Steam, so I got it, and now have mixed feelings about it.

    On one hand, there's more things in it, like, characters and moves and fatalities (if you get the XL version, that is).

    On the other hand, the single-player story mode is way too short (took me 5 hours on medium difficulty), and the "towers" mode is way too stingy with the in-game currency by comparison, so it'll take a lot of grinding to unlock all the unlocks (which can also be "conveniently" unlocked via a microtransaction. Ugh)

Books

  • A long list of Weird Fiction books on Goodreads

Music

  • The Love Dimension - Dream Decibels

    No exceptionally good albums this week, but have this very decent psychedelic rock LP that I've discovered at the last minute

item.title: I should probably change the design and remove these titles
item.description: Programming Wave Function Collapse An algorihtm that generates bitmaps that are locally similar to the input bitmap. Can be used for e.g‚Ä¶
item.content:encoded:
Programming

  • Wave Function Collapse

    An algorihtm that generates bitmaps that are locally similar to the input bitmap.

    Can be used for e.g. texture or dungeon generation.

    NB: Has nothing quantum or wave-functiony in it.

  • 3d City generator that uses it

Articles

  • Speaking of quantum theory, Quantum theory cannot consistently describe the use of itself

    Turns out, we'd need some new theory to describe both microscopic and macroscopic events ._.

Games

  • Diablo 1 is on GOG!

    I wonder if GOG's version includes this patch or merely a similar one.

Music

  • Sulphur Aeon - The Scythe of Cosmic Chaos

    Technical death metal in the vein of Nile, but 100% lovecraftian in theme.

  • Celtic Frost - Monotheist

    To me, this is easily Celtic Frost's best album (they later continued under the name Triptykon).

    Bought it on a CD a couple of weeks ago and can't be happier!

    (the link is to a slightly different Japanese release)

Art (?)

  • Very weird apartment for rent in Kyiv (archived page, not sure if works)

Programming

  • Why Don't People Use Formal Methods

    (because they are normally not worth the investment)

Articles

  • ETS isn't TLS and you should not use it

  • We Need Chrome No More

  • How Chickens Lost Their Penises

    Hard psychedelic rock, very psychedelic in fact. Highly recommended.

  • Marxthrone - A Blaze in the Western Sky

    And as for something completely different, here's a communist-themed black metal.

item.title: Links and updates
item.description: Programming C is Not a Low-level Language All programming languages are abstractions, in some way. Even simplistic ones, like C and x8‚Ä¶
item.content:encoded:
Programming

  • C is Not a Low-level Language

    All programming languages are abstractions, in some way. Even simplistic ones, like C and x86 assembly, are now quite far from the bare bones of the hardware (at least, in the x86-world) -- there's just too many layers of intermediate translations and optimizations that the CPU does by itself.

    RISC architectures are better in that regard, as even x86 CPUs are RISC-like internally nowadays (or so they say), so at least it's more transparent that way.

    Then again, as merely a front-end guy, I'm probably not the one to talk. Read the article instead.

Articles

  • (premium article) Is there Really a Fourth Neutrino
  • Why the Best Place to Find Dark Matter May Be in a Rock
  • Lightbulb lifetime conspiracy theories that are actually true
  • Ghost Kanji in japanese dictionaries

Music

  • Necrophobic - Mark of the Necrogram (spotify, amazon), a fast and furious black/death metal (as one may deduce from the band name, album title and the cover art).

    Highlights: easily Tsar-Bomba.

    Seen them perform live, also bought the CD.

Art

As for art, here's two depressive japanese artists on twitter:

  • https://twitter.com/avogado6
  • https://twitter.com/HamsterFragment

Books

  • Land of the Lustrous, a manga series that is qiute stylishly drawn.

    I got the first five volumes of it DRM-free in a humble bundle, but I'm not sure if that's currently an option.

    (Not that any of my two or so readers would have any troubles finding it DRM-free guerilla-style, if you know what I mean)

Technical updates

  • The CSS should now follow the browser's preferred theme (light or dark). I'm not sure how it works, so whether if it does or not, please let me know.

    A handy guide by David Walsh

item.title: Links and updates
item.description: In this post, I will try and gather some interesting stuff I found around the internets. Event sourcing is hard . I used to work on an large‚Ä¶
item.content:encoded:
In this post, I will try and gather some interesting stuff I found around the internets.

  • Event sourcing is hard. I used to work on an large product which was based on event-sourcing, and can agree on many points made by the author. It was very fun, but also a lot of pain.

    I guess, eventually, when the right tooling will be sourced, it will be usable... (Apache Kafka/Zamza come to mind; then again, it were these exact things that made us consider event-sourcing in the first place)

  • Anguish from rare noise records, an experimental mix of hip-hop and dark jazz improvisations.

  • The Prefect by Alastair Reynolds. Also a mix, but of hard sci-fi and murder mystery. Technically this book is in the same universe as his Revelation Space trilogy, but it's quite separate and reading other books is not required.

  • The Long History of the Mind-Bending ‚ÄòTiny Planet‚Äô Panorama, from Atlas Obscura

The only non-post update to this site is I've changed the "background" color in its manifest to my "brand" color, that is, #da5f51.

item.title: Hello
item.description: Hello and welcome to my personal space , where I will probably post random links for, like, two people to notice. I made it using gatsby‚Ä¶
item.content:encoded:
Hello and welcome to my personal space, where I will probably post random links for, like, two people to notice.

I made it using gatsby.js, and the experience was OK. In retrospect I think I should've used some better starter, and not try and bend the default one to my will. Oh well.

This whole thing seems to be working, so yay.

Here's a list of things that I still have to do at some point:

  • The posts page currently shows a list of all posts. This is fine for now, but surely in some distant future there will be more than, say, 10 posts and it'll require some sort of pagination.
  • The CV: I just copied it from the old version of this site without much retouching. Who cares, I'll update it when I need to :/
  • I should probably make a list of my pet projects? Except my old garbage games, who needs those.
